title: Create Application
content:
Create Application (Images 1–4) Open AWS Migration Hub.
Go to Applications.
Click Create Application.
Name your application and click Create.

title: Create IAM Role
content:
Create IAM Role (Images 42–46) Open IAM.
Roles → Create role.
Configure trust & permissions → Next.
Review → Create role.
Suggested: AmazonSSMManagedInstanceCore, S3 read if needed, and SAP deployment requirements.

title: Create VPC
content:
Create VPC (Images 20–23) Open VPC service.
Your VPCs → Create VPC.
Configure as per architecture.
Create VPC.

title: ERP System Migration with SAP on AWS
content:
ERP System Migration with SAP on AWS Overall In this lab, you will migrate an ERP system running SAP workloads to AWS.
You will set up AWS Migration Hub, import server inventory, build the network (VPC, NAT, endpoints), configure IAM, launch EC2, and deploy SAP using AWS Launch Wizard.
Content Introduction Preparation AWS Migration Hub Network Setup IAM & EC2 SAP Deployment (Launch Wizard) Verification Cleanup

title: Introduction
content:
Introduction SAP is a leading ERP platform. Migrating SAP to AWS brings scalability, resiliency, and cost efficiency.
What you will do:
Use AWS Migration Hub to track applications and imported servers. Build VPC networking (NAT, routes, endpoints). Configure IAM and launch EC2. Deploy SAP with AWS Launch Wizard. Verify and clean up. Target audience: Cloud/SAP engineers familiar with AWS Console basics.

title: Select Workload & Pattern
content:
Workload Library & Pattern (Images 52–55) Open AWS Launch Wizard.
Workload Library → SAP → Launch new deployment.
Choose deployment pattern → Configure deployment.
Start entering parameters.

title: Configure Deployment
content:
Configure Deployment (Images 56–61) Proceed through wizard sections and fill parameters as shown:
Section 1
Section 2
Section 3
Section 4
Section 5
Section 6

title: Create NAT Gateway
content:
NAT Gateway (Images 24–27) Open NAT Gateways.
Click Create NAT Gateway.
Configure as shown → Create.
NAT Gateway created.

title: Create S3 Bucket & Upload File
content:
Create S3 Bucket & Upload (Images 5–10) Open Amazon S3.
Click Create bucket.
Enter bucket name.
Review and create.
Bucket created.
Open the bucket → Upload the inventory file.

title: Launch EC2 Instance
content:
Launch EC2 (Images 47–51) Open EC2.
Click Launch instance.
Configure AMI / type / network as shown.
Launch instance.

title: Preparation
content: Preparation AWS Account & Region: use one region for all resources. Services: Migration Hub, S3, VPC, EC2, IAM, Launch Wizard. Permissions: Admin or equivalent. Artifacts: a CSV/JSON server inventory file for 2 servers (import to Migration Hub). Tip: keep all names/tags consistent (e.g., erp-lab-*).

title: AWS Migration Hub
content:
AWS Migration Hub You will: create an Application, upload inventory to S3, Import servers, and attach to the Application.
Pages Create Application Create S3 Bucket & Upload File Import Servers from S3 Attach Servers to Application

title: Import Servers from S3
content:
Import Servers (Images 11–16) Start upload → Upload.
Select the uploaded file → Copy S3 URL.
Go to Tools.
Click Import.
Enter import name, paste S3 URL → Import.
Verify Servers tab shows 2 servers.

title: Review & Deploy
content:
Review & Deploy (Image 62) Final review.
Click Deploy and wait for completion (tens of minutes typical).

title: Route Tables
content:
Route Tables (Images 28–29) Open Route Tables and follow edits.
Edit routes → Save changes.

title: Attach Servers to Application
content:
Attach Servers to Application (Images 17–19) Go to Applications, select the app → Actions → Add server to application.
Select both imported servers → Add.
Application now shows 2 servers.

title: Network Setup
content:
Network Setup You will create VPC, NAT Gateway, configure Route Tables, and add VPC Endpoints (S3, SSM, EC2Messages, SSMMessages).
Pages Create VPC Create NAT Gateway Route Tables VPC Endpoints

title: VPC Endpoints
content:
VPC Endpoints (Images 30–41) Open Endpoints.
Click Create endpoint (you will create 4 endpoints).
Endpoint 1 — S3 (Gateway) Choose service ending with .s3.
Configure as shown.
Create endpoint.
Endpoint 2 — SSM (Interface) Service ending with .ssm.
Configure and create.
Check it appears.
Endpoint 3 — EC2Messages (Interface) Service ending with .ec2messages.
Endpoint 4 — SSMMessages (Interface) Service ending with .ssmmessages.
Verify Confirm all endpoints are listed.

title: IAM & EC2
content:
IAM & EC2 You will create an IAM Role for instances, then launch EC2 with appropriate sizing for SAP.
Pages Create IAM Role Launch EC2 Instance

title: SAP Deployment (Launch Wizard)
content:
SAP Deployment (Launch Wizard) Use AWS Launch Wizard for SAP to provision the SAP landscape according to your parameters.
Pages Select Workload & Pattern Configure Deployment Review & Deploy

title: Verification
content: Verification EC2: All SAP-related instances are running and reachable (via SSM/Session Manager or your chosen access). Network: VPC routes via NAT work; endpoints (S3, SSM, EC2Messages, SSMMessages) are available. SAP: Validate basic connectivity and services start-up as per your pattern. Logs: Check CloudWatch/Application logs for errors.

title: Cleanup
content:
Cleanup Delete lab resources to avoid charges:
EC2 instances NAT Gateway(s) VPC Endpoints Route entries / (optionally) VPC S3 bucket objects/bucket IAM role(s) Migration Hub application & server records
